questions.question_text: When VPNs are grouped to create destination zone in Zone-Based Firewall, how many zones can a single VPN be part of?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A VPN can be part of only one zone.
Given answer is correct https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/config-18-4.pdf#page=242

questions.question_text: An engineer wants to track tunnel characteristics within a SLA-based policy for convergence. Which policy configuration will achieve this goal?

comments.content:
I agree. Answer is A . 

An application-aware routing policy matches applications with an SLA, that is, with the data plane tunnel performance characteristics that are necessary to transmit the applications' data traffic. The primary purpose of application-aware routing policy is to optimize the path for data traffic being transmitted by Cisco SD-WAN devices.

discussion.content:
correct answer should be A
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/vedge/policies-book/application-aware-routing.html

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
SLA based tracking is in APP route policy

Selected Answer: A
Totally A

vSmart1(config)# policy ?
Possible completions:
 app-route-policy Configure application-aware routing policy
 cflowd-template Configure cflowd template
 control-policy List of control policies
 data-policy Configure data policy
 lists Configure lists
 policer Configure policer
 sla-class Configure SLA classes for application-aware routing
 vpn-membership List of VPN membership policies
 <cr>

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: A
correct answer should be A
app-route policy

• Control Policies are applied at vSmart: Tailors routing information advertised to WAN endpoints
• App-Route Policies are applied at WAN Edge: SLA-driven path selection for applications
• Data Policies are applied at WAN Edge: Extensive Policy driven routing

https://www.ciscolive.com/c/dam/r/ciscolive/us/docs/2019/pdf/BRKRST-2791.pdf
page 6
I will go with D , Cisco's word game. app-route policy is not the correct naming, it should have been app-aware routing, which is in essence a centralized data policy.

comments.content: and even more the question is tricky, they said that the engineer wants to configured SLA for a future use in app-aware

discussion.content: D is correct
Application aware routing policy is a data policy so this question is a bit... dirty. But the book also specified this is done via an app-route policy. A is correct.

comments.content: I think it's under centralized policy when you select sequences... but I'm not 100% sure
but it is "app-route-policy" in the CLI

Exactly what you say, tricky question this. You reach the right policy via Centralized -> Application Aware Routing. 'app-route' isn't mentioned anywhere in the GUI I think. I'll answer this with D since data policy is an actual term Cisco uses.

questions.question_text: An administrator needs to configure Cisco SD-WAN to divert traffic from the company's private network to an ISP network. Which action should be taken to accomplish this goal?

discussion.content:
C is correct
The key word is Divert Traffic which you do with data policy.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
Correct Answer B

Selected Answer: C
I think the intention of this question is, to forward traffic from the LAN-Side to the Service-Provider (Underlay). This configuration would be done in a Traffic-Data-Policy. Answer C can be the only option. The AAR-Policy is only for SLA-Routing Side-To-Side
maybe the question is related to another ISP to an external ISP that is not in the overlay and NAT is needed so thats why "centralized data policy" can work also (answ C)
Not sure what the intention is of the question. A control policy can be used to prefer ISP color over private network color for the whole topology.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the definitions from the left to the configuration on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
given answer is correct as cisco docs-


Firewall policy—A security policy, similar to a localized security policy, that defines the conditions that the data traffic flow from the source zone must match to allow the flow to continue to the destination zone. Firewall policies can match IP prefixes, IP ports, the protocols TCP, UDP, ICMP, and applications. Matching flows for prefixes, ports, and protocols can be accepted or dropped, and the packet headers can be logged. Nonmatching flows are dropped by default. Matching applications are denied.

Zone pair—A container that associates a source zone with a destination zone and that applies a firewall policy to the traffic that flows between the two zones.

I will go with the given answer, as per the link
Zone configuration consists of the following components:

Source zone—A grouping of VPNs where the data traffic flows originate. A VPN can be part of only one zone.

Destination zone—A grouping of VPNs where the data traffic flows terminate. A VPN can be part of only one zone.

Firewall policy—A security policy, similar to a localized security policy, that defines the conditions that the data traffic flow from the source zone must match to allow the flow to continue to the destination zone. Firewall policies can match IP prefixes, IP ports, the protocols TCP, UDP, and ICMP. Matching flows for prefixes, ports, and protocols can be accepted or dropped, and the packet headers can be logged. Nonmatching flows are dropped by default.

Zone pair—A container that associates a source zone with a destination zone and that applies a firewall policy to the traffic that flows between the two zones.

Given answer mixed up firewall policy and zone pair
I will go for B -> A -> D -> C as well
Given answer is correct
https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/config-18-2.pdf#page=474
should be B -> A -> D -> C

Selected Answer: A
vsmart is the component that deploy policies to WAN Edges.
